text.p: Consider the list of vectors [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline], where

Can you find scalars [mathjaxinline]a_1, a_2, a_3[/mathjaxinline], not all zero, such that [mathjaxinline]a_1v_1 + a_2 v_2 + a_3 v_3 = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]? If so, enter an example of such scalars below. If not, enter ‘No'
Is the list [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] linearly dependent or linearly independent?

font.p:
Notice that [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline] is the only vector in the set with non-zero entries in the third and fourth positions; a zero combination of these vectors therefore requires [mathjaxinline]a_2 = 0[/mathjaxinline]. Then, notice that [mathjaxinline]-3 \cdot v_1 = v_3[/mathjaxinline], so that [mathjaxinline]3 \cdot v_1 + 1 \cdot v_3 = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]. We have that [mathjaxinline]a_1 = 3[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]a_2 = 0[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]a_3 = 1[/mathjaxinline] is a possible set of scalars that satisfies the equation. It follows that any scalar multiple of that triple is also a set that satisfies the equation. Furthermore, it is easy to show that the coefficients that satisfy the equation can only be scalar multiples of that triple.
The set [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is linearly dependent because, as we've just seen, there exist sets of coefficients, not all zero, that make the above equation true.
